comment_data.body: hmm, `vim_strnsize` needs to be fixed to use `utfc_ptr2len_len`. after that we could eliminate mb_string2cells_len. It is only used in one other place and deleting a redundant but buggy function would be good.

That defeats the point of this PR. `utfc_ptr2len_len` treats control characters as 1-wide. I think all functions in `mbyte.c` treat control characters as 1-wide. Maybe some other functions depend on them treating control characters as 1-wide.
BTW I also created <https://github.com/vim/vim/pull/9369> at the same when I created this PR.

@zeertzjq what point? utfc_ptr2len_len is just the same as utfc_ptr2len except that it actually uses the width. sending a ptr,size pair to `vim_strnsize` is completely pointless if size is ignored and it still reads past the end of `ptr+size`. the *width* calculation itself should not change, which I never suggested.
The point of this PR is to disallow control characters as border by detecting them as multi-width, like <https://github.com/vim/vim/pull/9369>.
that's fine, but if there is a memory correctness issue, why not fix it at the same time?

By `wide` I mean cells here. `vim_strnsize` doesn't check for byte length of a string. It checks for how many cells it occupies, and it detects control characters as multi-cells by calling `ptr2cells` instead of `utf_ptr2cells`.

`vim_strnsize` takes a ptr/size pair. this implies it shouldn't access memory beyond `ptr+size`. this is trivial to fix by using utfc_ptr2len_len. This doesn't affect width calculation in any way. with this change `mb_string2cells_len` can be eliminated and `vim_strnsize` always be used in its place (only one more place). In addition, the latter can be renamed if we so want, but that's secondary to actually fixing the issue.

For `gM` something other than `mb_string2cells_len` and `vim_strnsize` should be needed, as it needs to take Tab width into consideration. I've reported this it Vim (<https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/9409>). `vim_strnsize` may be needed for some virtual text related stuff.
Oh, I finally understood what you meant.

comment_regular_data.body: I'm no longer interested in this. There are other places where control chars cause problems (e.g. virtual text) and it's not really a big problem as long as Nvim doesn't crash.

title: fix(float): do not allow control characters as border
